user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY) && defined(HAVE_GETPID)
  /* Glibc style */
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    cpu_set_t cur_set;
    if (0 == sched_getaffinity (getpid (), sizeof (cur_set), &cur_set))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT
      ret = CPU_COUNT (&cur_set);
#else  /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
      unsigned int i;
      ret = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE; ++i)
      {
        if (CPU_ISSET (i, &cur_set))
          ++ret;
      }
      if (0 == ret)
        ret = -1;
#endif /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
    }
  }
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Use 256 times larger size than size for default maximum CPU number.
       Hopefully it would be enough even for exotic situations. */
    static const unsigned int set_size_cpus = 256 * CPU_SETSIZE;
    const size_t set_size_bytes = CPU_ALLOC_SIZE (set_size_cpus);
    cpu_set_t *p_set;

    p_set = CPU_ALLOC (set_size_cpus);
    if (NULL != p_set)
    {
      if (0 == sched_getaffinity (getpid (), set_size_bytes, p_set))
      {
#ifndef MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (set_size_bytes, p_set);
#else  /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (set_size_cpus, p_set);
#endif /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
      }
      CPU_FREE (p_set);
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S */
#endif /* HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY && HAVE_GETPID */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The listed fragments contain controlling expressions that can become invariant depending on preprocessor configuration or compile-time constants, and thus should be investigated for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Other conditional and loop expressions in the function do not need investigation for this rule because they clearly depend on runtime-varying values or function results: - Conditions that test return values of function calls (e.g. sched_getaffinity checks) depend on runtime behavior. - Pointer-null checks (if (NULL != p_set)) depend on the result of CPU_ALLOC at runtime. - The if (0 == ret) after counting depends on the runtime outcome of the counting loop. - The CPU_ISSET test inside the loop depends on runtime data (cur_set). - The expressions that use loop variables (i < CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE) normally vary as i changes; they only become problematic if CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE is zero at compile time, which is why the for line itself was included in the suspicious list for explicit checking. These runtime-dependent expressions therefore do not represent obvious invariant controlling expressions and were not included in the suspicious list.
